repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
(Don't mind the labeler bot, I made a Git oopsie)

fix https://github.com/neovim/neovim.github.io/issues/380

- Generates a `helptags.json` that maps tags to their location (`foo.html#bar`).
    - This lets other clients fetch the json for whatever purpose.
- Generates an html page `helptag.html` that accepts a `?tag=foo` parameter and redirects the user to the docs of that tag.

~~The html page should probably just live in the doc2 directory of https://github.com/neovim/neovim.github.io~~

Examples:

- https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag='number' → https://neovim.io/doc/user/options.html#'number'
- https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=notexistingtag → https://neovim.io/doc/user/index.html

comment_data.body:
let's name it `tags.json`

it will live under `doc/tags.json`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1301,6 +1362,8 @@ function M.gen(help_dir, to_dir, include, commit, parser_path)
   print(('output dir: %s\n\n'):format(to_dir))
   vim.fn.mkdir(to_dir, 'p')
   gen_css(('%s/help.css'):format(to_dir))
+  gen_tagindex_json(vim.fs.joinpath(to_dir, 'tagindex.json'))

comment_data.body:
let's name the html page `tag` (singular), it will live under `doc/tag.html`

```suggestion
  gen_tagindex_html(vim.fs.joinpath(to_dir, 'tag.html'))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1301,6 +1362,8 @@ function M.gen(help_dir, to_dir, include, commit, parser_path)
   print(('output dir: %s\n\n'):format(to_dir))
   vim.fn.mkdir(to_dir, 'p')
   gen_css(('%s/help.css'):format(to_dir))
+  gen_tagindex_json(vim.fs.joinpath(to_dir, 'tagindex.json'))
+  gen_tagindex_html(vim.fs.joinpath(to_dir, 'tagindex.html'))

comment_data.body: I chose `tagindex` as it's less likely to be a helpfile name (and I think tags.txt (plural) already exists. Lmk what you think.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1301,6 +1362,8 @@ function M.gen(help_dir, to_dir, include, commit, parser_path)
   print(('output dir: %s\n\n'):format(to_dir))
   vim.fn.mkdir(to_dir, 'p')
   gen_css(('%s/help.css'):format(to_dir))
+  gen_tagindex_json(vim.fs.joinpath(to_dir, 'tagindex.json'))
+  gen_tagindex_html(vim.fs.joinpath(to_dir, 'tagindex.html'))

comment_data.body: good thinking, but not worried about that :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1301,6 +1362,8 @@ function M.gen(help_dir, to_dir, include, commit, parser_path)
   print(('output dir: %s\n\n'):format(to_dir))
   vim.fn.mkdir(to_dir, 'p')
   gen_css(('%s/help.css'):format(to_dir))
+  gen_tagindex_json(vim.fs.joinpath(to_dir, 'tagindex.json'))
+  gen_tagindex_html(vim.fs.joinpath(to_dir, 'tagindex.html'))

comment_regular_data.body: Thanks! This saves me some work. Can keep improving it or try other approaches later. Also, the json file could be useful for other clients that want to just download all the tags as json.

Sure, np! I don't have much time to work on it this weekend, so if you feel like continuing the work, sure do :)

Other approaches I considered:
- Jekyll native "categories": doesn't fit the many-tags-on-one-page and tag-at-anchor case
- for every tag, have it's own html page `doc/tags/<tag>.html` that redirects to the right doc page. Not sure how I feel about this one.

Ok I'll pick this up. 



>  or every tag, have it's own html page `doc/tags/<tag>.html`

yeah [added that to ideas](https://github.com/neovim/neovim.github.io/issues/380#issuecomment-3216156797) but probably doesn't serve much purpose, except maybe to avoid the big download of all the tags for clients that haven't already cached it.

@yochem, thanks for the work!

It seems to work as expected, although some special looking tags do not work showing `Redirecting… ` page. Here are the ones that I found:
- [`#`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=#), [`#{}`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=#{}), [`&`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=&) - `No tag parameter`.
- [`-+`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=-+) - `helptag not found: "- "`.

Maybe there are others.
Thanks! May be due to the url_encode? Can't test it rn, sorry.

> * [`#`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=#), [`#{}`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=#%7B%7D), [`&`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=&) - `No tag parameter`.
> * [`-+`](https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=-+) - `helptag not found: "- "`.

You need to url-encode those tags. `#` is an obvious one :)

- https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=%23
- https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=%23%7B%7D
- https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=%26
- https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html?tag=-%2B

> You need to url-encode those tags. `#` is an obvious one :)

Yeah, I thought so. But the fact that some work and some don't was suspicious to me. Options like `'complete'` work as is, for example.

And yeah, encoding it on the user side might be difficult. Maybe it can somehow be done here instead (not a web dev expert)? For example, [this solution](https://github.com/neovim/neovim.github.io/issues/380#issuecomment-3215295829) works with `-+` and `&`, but, as I understand, it is not "static site friendly".

> For example, [this solution](https://github.com/neovim/neovim.github.io/issues/380#issuecomment-3215295829) works with `-+` and `&`, but, as I understand, it is not "static site friendly".

That still requires uri-encoding, try this: https://neovim-doc-browser.gpanders.workers.dev/#

It also requires a cloudflare token in our CI, or manually deploying the worker. It's an option we will keep open but adds a maintenance cost.

Potential follow-up:

https://neovim.io/doc/user/helptag.html without tag parameter shows an index of tags, similar to the json file. Easy to add and could also be useful for users. I understand they can also use the json file (which we can mention on the helptags.html page), but might be helpful for non-tech users.

What do you think?
idk, let's not invest too much until people actually ask for it or provide a use-case

title: Generate tagindex for website docs
